unnormalised: Okay, so my friend Raju is planning a trip, right? He's finally taking his family to Disneyland! Problem is, Raju is, well, let’s just say he's not exactly a "time zone guru." He called me yesterday, all panicked, asking about when to call his relatives in the US to tell them they're coming. He lives in Kolkata, so that's IST – Indian Standard Time.
normalised: Okay, so my friend Raju is planning a trip, right? He is finally taking his family to Disneyland! Problem is, Raju is, well, let us just say he is not exactly a "time zone guru." He called me yesterday, all panicked, asking about when to call his relatives in the U-S to tell them they are coming. He lives in Kolkata, so that is I-S-T – Indian Standard Time.

unnormalised: First, he asked, "If it's 2 PM here in Kolkata, what time is it in Los Angeles?" I nearly choked on my chai! Los Angeles, Raju? You're going to need more than just a lucky guess! I explained, very patiently, that LA is in the Pacific Time Zone (PST) during standard time and PDT (Pacific Daylight Time) during daylight saving time. Which is currently in effect! So there's that complexity to consider.
normalised: First, he asked, "If it is two P-M here in Kolkata, what time is it in Los Angeles?" I nearly choked on my chai! Los Angeles, Raju? You are going to need more than just a lucky guess! I explained, very patiently, that L-A is in the Pacific Time Zone (P-S-T) during standard time and P-D-T (Pacific Daylight Time) during daylight saving time. Which is currently in effect! So there is that complexity to consider.

unnormalised: Then, he throws another curveball. "What about Orlando?" he asks. Orlando, being in Florida, is on Eastern Time. So that's EST or EDT, depending on daylight saving. Honestly, I felt like I was teaching a geography lesson! He seemed genuinely surprised that the US isn't just one big timezone blob. Poor fellow thought he could just add or subtract a couple of hours and be done with it.
normalised: Then, he throws another curveball. "What about Orlando?" he asks. Orlando, being in Florida, is on Eastern Time. So that is E-S-T or E-D-T, depending on daylight saving. Honestly, I felt like I was teaching a geography lesson! He seemed genuinely surprised that the U-S is not just one big timezone blob. Poor fellow thought he could just add or subtract a couple of hours and be done with it.

unnormalised: The best part? He wanted to know the precise minute difference. Like, if it's 2:03 PM IST, what exact minute it is in LA. I had to explain that time zones usually work in whole-hour offsets, though there are some quirky exceptions like Nepal Standard Time which is GMT+5:45. Can you imagine the confusion if everyone operated on such precise, non-standard offsets? Meetings would start at all sorts of weird times!

I had to explain that time zones usually work in whole-hour offsets, though there are some quirky exceptions like Nepal Standard Time which is G-M-T plus five forty five. Can you imagine the confusion if everyone operated on such precise, non-standard offsets? Meetings would start at all sorts of weird times!

unnormalised: I also had to remind him about daylight saving time. He was all, "Daylight...what now?" I explained that most of the US observes DST, which means springing forward one hour in the summer. This completely blew his mind. "So," he said, "the time actually...changes?" I could almost see the gears grinding in his head, trying to process this mind-bending concept.

unnormalised: Finally, after much explaining and a few helpful websites, Raju seemed to grasp the basics. He even (attempted) to calculate the time difference himself. He was off by about 3 hours, but hey, at least he tried! I told him to just use a time zone converter and stop giving me a headache.
